STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
February 26, 2020
Zoe Lyons
Jackson County DHHS
301 E Louis Glick Highway
Jackson, MI 49201
RE: License #: CP380201203
Jackson County DHHS
301 E Louis Glick Highway
Jackson, MI 49201
Dear Ms. Lyons:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on 2/12/2020.
Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and Modified
Settlement Agreement (MISEP) requirements, a written corrective action plan is required.
It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP
and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved. For repeat
violations, please address steps from previous CAPs, what actions
have been successful, and what areas need to be adjusted to ensure
compliance going forward.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (269) 337-5289.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
22 Center Street
Ypsilanti, MI 48198
(734) 660-8309
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP380201203
Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Address: 235 South Grand Avenue
Lansing, MI 48902
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 373-3768
Administrator/Licensee Designee: Jooyeun Chang, Designee
Zoey Lyons, Designee
Name of Facility: Jackson County DHHS
Facility Address: 301 E Louis Glick Highway
Jackson, MI 49201
Facility Telephone #: (517) 780-7400
Original Issuance Date: 03/01/1992
Service Types: PLACE CHILDREN IN FOSTER HOMES
CERTIFY FOSTER HOMES FOR
LICENSURE
SUPERVISE INDEPENDENT LIVING
PLACE CHILDREN FOR ADOPTION
1

Date of On-site Inspection(s): 01/10/2020 – 2/12/2020

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and shall make a
licensing recommendation to the department at least 15
calendar days before the expiration date of the foster home
license.
Eight licensing files were reviewed. Four files required a renewal evaluation during
this review period. Two of four files did not meet this requirement.
File 1: License expiration date of 8/7/19, the renewal was not completed/approved
until 8/2/19.
File 2: License expiration date of 11/20/19, the renewal was not completed/approved
until 11/7/19.
REPEAT VIOLATION:
1/15/19 licensing renewal, CAP approved 2/6/19.
2/9/18 interim licensing review, CAP approved 3/2/18.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of the
following information:
(d) Dates and places of contacts, names of persons
interviewed, and names of the interviewers. If children are
interviewed, their last names shall not be included in the report.
Two of two special evaluation reports did not meet this requirement. Both reports
identified minor children by last name.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the child's
record before a change of placement occurs:
(a)Reason for the change in placement…
(4) If an emergency change in placement is necessary, then all
of the documentation required in subrule (2) and (3) of this rule
shall be in the child’s record within 14 calendar days after the
change in placement.
4

Six of eight foster care files did not meet this requirement.
File one: The youth moved from residential, to psychiatric hospitalization, then to
another residential without a DHHS 69 being completed.
File two: The youth returned home on 11/7/19. A DHHS 69 was completed late
(12/26/19).
File three: The youth moved to residential on 5/17/19, then moved again on 7/31/19.
DHHS 69s were not completed within 15 days of these moves.
File four: The youth moved on 8/30/19 and again on 10/29/19. A DHHS 69 was not
completed for either move.
File five: The youth moved on 6/25/19; a DHHS 69 was not completed until
10/31/19. The youth moved again on 7/2/19; a DHHS 69 was not completed until
1/9/2020.
File six: The youth moved on 12/3/19; a DHHS 69 was not completed until 1/8/2020.
REPEAT VIOLATION:
This is a repeat violation from the 2/9/18 interim licensing review, CAP
approved 3/2/18.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An Agency’s medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(c, iii) A physical examination every 14 months.
(f, ii) A dental reexamination shall be obtained at least every 18
months, unless a greater frequency is indicated.
(2) An agency shall have documentation from the medical or
dental provider of all medical and dental care received by a
foster child.
One of eight foster care files did not meet this requirement.
The youth’s last dental exam was 1/22/18. The agency reported that follow up dental
visits occurred on 2/6/19, 2/12/19 and 8/10/19, but no documentation was on file to
verify these visits. In addition, Youth A’s last medical was noted in the file as
7/24/19, but there was no documentation on file to verify this.
R 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement of a
child…
5

One of eight foster care files did not meet this requirement. When the youth changed
placement, there was no documentation on file to show that the required information
was provided to the new foster parent.
R 400.12510 Independent living contract.
(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the youth and
the social service worker. The contract shall be reviewed and
updated at least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided to the youth.
One of three independent living case files did not have an IL contract signed
quarterly. The file had a contract signed in June and November 2019. A contract
should have been signed in September 2019.
REPEAT VIOLATION:
1/15/19 licensing renewal, CAP approved 2/6/19.
2/9/18 interim licensing review, CAP approved 3/2/18.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter
One of eight foster care files held USPs that were completed late.
 USP was due 11/12/19, completed 11/15/19.
 USP due 8/13/19, completed 8/20/19.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance with all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MDHHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional MDHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance with all additional MDHHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
FOM 723 Educational services
Page 17
All educational information and related tasks, activities, and
contacts must be documented within the social work contacts,
6

case service plans, placement, and the education section of
MiSACWIS.
Information regarding special education services and IEPs must
be documented in MiSACWIS. This includes uploading a copy
of the IEP into the education section of MiSACWIS.
Two of eight foster care cases did not have current information uploaded into the
education section of MiSACWIS. One file did not have any updated school/grade
information, or report cards. The second file was last updated in January 2019, and
must be updated to reflect the end of that school year, and the beginning of the
current school year.
FOM 801 Medical passport
Page 11-13
For each child in foster care the supervising agency must
maintain a medical passport containing all items listed in MCL
722.954c.
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's
current and complete health information.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• Legal parents, if the child is a temporary court ward. Quarterly.
At reunification.
• The child’s foster care provider: At or prior to each placement.
Quarterly.
Older youth
7

Five of eleven foster care and independent living files did not meet this requirement.
FC file one: 4/30/10 passport did not have information from the 12/19/18 medical
exam. Passports were not updated quarterly; the only passports on file were from
April 2019 and January 2020.
FC file two: No medical passports were on file.
FC file three: A quarterly updated medical passport had a note that it was sent to jail
for an incarcerated parent signature. However, it did not note which parent it was
sent to as both parents are in jail. No parental signatures were received. In addition,
an updated medical passport for December 2019 was not on file.
IL file one: The September 2019 passport is missing the youth signature to show
that it was provided to the youth.
IL file two: One medical passport is on file for June 2018, no further passports were
uploaded until August 2019. None have been uploaded since.
REPEAT VIOLATION:
1/15/19 licensing renewal, CAP approved 2/6/19.
2/9/18 interim licensing review, CAP approved 3/2/18.
FOM 722-08C Parent agency treatment plans
Page 9
When completed, obtain all signatures as appropriate, including
those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care worker, supervisor,
foster parent, caregiver, any youth age 14 and older and in the
case of placement agency foster care cases, the local DHS
office designee.
CI 17-096 Treatment Plan Signature Timeframes and
Documentation Requirements: When the treatment plan is
completed, signatures for all appropriate case members must
be obtained. Signatures from all appropriate case members,
including youth ages 14 and older for foster care and youth
ages 11 and older for juvenile justice, should be obtained before
the corresponding court hearing. All treatment plans with a
report date of August 1, 2017, or later must have signatures
from all appropriate case members within 30 days of the report
date.
8

Three of eight foster care files did not meet this requirement.
File one: The 4/12/19, 7/11/19 and 10/2/19 PATPs did not have a youth signature
until 1/9/20.
File two: The 6/26/19 PATP was not signed by the parent until 10/1/19. The 9/24/19
PATP was not signed by the parent until 11/26/19. The 9/24/19 PATP is also
missing the father and caregiver’s signatures. The 12/23/19 PATP is missing the
both parent and caregiver’s signatures.
File three: The 5/15/19 PATP was signed by the foster parent, but not dated.
Therefore, it could not be determined if the signature was within the 30 day
timeframe.
REPEAT VIOLATION:
This is a repeat violation from the 2/9/18 interim licensing review, CAP
approved 3/2/18.
FOM 722-06H Caseworker contact with supervisor
Page 12
The caseworker must meet with his/her supervisor at least
monthly for case consultation on every active case.
Two of eight foster care case files were missing monthly supervision.
File one: Supervision was not documented for June or October 2019.
File two: Supervision was not documented for July 2019.
REPEAT VIOLATION:
This is a repeat violation from the 2/9/18 interim licensing review, CAP
approved 3/2/18.
FOM 722-06B Family team meeting
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as outlined in
the following tables:
 Updated Case Plan (USP) - Within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
 Semi-Annual Transition Meeting- Within 30 calendar
days after the youth’s 14th birthday and every six months
thereafter.
The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report, is used to
capture family demographics, FTM logistical information, needs,
strengths, action steps, safety concerns and the safety plan,
and any recommendations made for the family during the FTM.
The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report, must be
completed at the conclusion of the FTM.
9

Three of eight foster care files did not meet this requirement.
File one:
 July, October and December 2019 USPs do not have an FTM documented
within 30 days prior to report due date.
 An 1105 report was not completed for the March 2019 FTM.
 A semi-annual transition meeting has not been completed since 5/31/17.
File two:
 The 8/27/19 FTM report was not completed until 9/24/19.
 FTMs were not completed prior to the 3/29/19 and 6/29/19 USPs.
File two:
 An FTM was not completed prior to the 5/9/19 USP.
REPEAT VIOLATION:
1/15/19 licensing renewal, CAP approved 2/6/19.
2/9/18 interim licensing review, CAP approved 3/2/18.
FOM 722-06H Timely entry of casework contacts
Page 15
All case contacts must be entered in MiSACWIS, including
attempted contacts and missed appointments. The case contact
narrative should consist of a brief summary of the contact.
Significant information obtained during the contact must be
summarized in the appropriate section of the case service plan.
The caseworker must enter the required face-to-face contacts
listed below in MISACWIS within five business days of the
contact. This includes attempted and missed face-to-face
contacts.
Four of eight foster care files held contacts that were entered into MiSACWIS
ranging from 10-60 days late.
REPEAT VIOLATION:
1/15/19 licensing renewal, CAP approved 2/6/19.
2/9/18 interim licensing review, CAP approved 3/2/18.
FOM 722-08 Supervisory approval
Page 23
Case service plan approval process requires the foster care
supervisor to:
• Review and approve the USP within 14 calendar days of the
report date.
10

Three foster care and independent living files held service plans with late supervisor
approval.
File one: 2/13/19 USP was not approved until 3/1/19.
File two: 4/21/19 USP was not approved until 5/7/19.
File three: 5/9/19 USP was not approved until 5/29/19.
REPEAT VIOLATION:
1/15/19 licensing renewal, CAP approved 2/6/19.
2/9/18 interim licensing review, CAP approved 3/2/18.
FOM 801 Health services for children in foster care
Page 4
Dental examinations are required for children 3 years of age
and older, as follows:
-A dental examination within six months before entry into foster
care or an initial dental examination shall be completed not
more than 90 calendar days after entry into a foster care out-of-
home placement.
-Children entering foster care under 3 years of age must have
an initial dental exam within three months of his/her third
birthday.
One of eight foster care files did not meet this requirement. The youth turned three
on 11/27/19, but a dental was not completed until 3/21/19.
IV. DCWL ANALYST
No safety concerns were identified by the DCWL analyst.
V. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility did not require technical assistance.
VI. CONSULTATION
The facility did not request consultation during this review.
VII. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period. A CAP was approved on 2/6/19, after the
1/15/19 renewal evaluation. The agency continues to follow, and adjust their CAP as
11

needed. Although there were some non-safety related, repeat violations, the agency
continues to show improvement in several areas.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules, MISEP requirements, or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on a
regular license.
February 13, 2020
Heather Reilly Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
February 26, 2020
Claudia Triestram Date
Area Manager
12
